Let's demonstrate that infinite sets can have different sizes. An extremely cunning but relatively simple argument by George Cantor (referred to as his diagonalization argument) demonstrates that the cardinality of is different from . To simplify the argument, we will consider only real numbers in the interval (0,1). If we can show that (0,1) is bigger than , then it follows that must be bigger, too.

First suppose that there is a one-one function between the natural numbers and the real numbers in the interval [0,1]. It might look like this:

The numbers on the left are the natural numbers and those on the right are the decimal expansions of numbers in the interval (0,1) to which each natural number gets mapped by our function1.

The key part of the argument is that whatever the rule for this one-one function, it cannot be onto, in other words there must be some numbers in (0,1) that it misses. In fact it is relatively straightforward to construct one. In true mathematical fashion, we'll call this number and will construct it digit by digit.

  • The natural number 1 gets mapped to 0.192405... The first digit in the decimal expansion of this real number is 1, so we will make the first digit in the decimal expansion of to be something different, say 2.
  • The natural number 2 gets mapped to 0.739287... The second digit of this real number is 3, so we will make the second digit of to be something different, say 8.
  • The natural number 3 gets mapped to 0.001001... The third digit of this real number is 1, so we will let the third digit of be something different, say 4.

So = 0.284 ...

The point is that if we continue in this manner, we will have a real number that cannot be in in the list on the right. It can't be the first number, because it's first digit is not the same as the first number's digit. It can't be the second number, because it's second digit is not the same as the second number's digit, and so forth.

So there is a number that is not mapped to by an natural number on the left. Therefore the function is not onto and hence not a bijection.

So (0,1) and hence are bigger than , and . Indeed, it turns out that is so much bigger than that if you were to throw a dart at the real number line, the probability that it would hit a rational number is effectively zero!

Which of the following might be a valid alternative for in the way that it's construction has been outlined above?
The nth digit of must be different from the nth digit of the nth real number in the list.

1 It is worth emphasising that every real number between 0 and 1 can be represented as an infinite decimal expansion 0. abcdef ...., which may be non-repeating, or repeating, or just zeros after a while. Clearly we can't write down the full expansion. What we are doing here is sketching the argument by looking at the first few digits as shown above.
